Total_Summary_Homelessness.Total_Homelessness_Annotation: Across the Philippines, 895 people died due to Agnes, with 272 people listed missing and 2,526 others wounded. A total of 491,968 people were evacuated to shelter in 27 provinces. More than 200,000 homes were destroyed while 163,056 other dwellings were damaged.

Total_Homelessness_Per_Country.Homelessness_with_annotation: Across the Philippines, 895 people died due to Agnes, with 272 people listed missing and 2,526 others wounded. A total of 491,968 people were evacuated to shelter in 27 provinces. More than 200,000 homes were destroyed while 163,056 other dwellings were damaged.

The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened. Throughout the country, the storm destroyed 271,000 hectares (670,000 acres) of farmland.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Homelessne.Homelessness_with_annotation: In the Iloilo province, 230 people were killed and four others were injured. Provincewide, a total of 21 homes were flattened, resulting in 1,326 homeless people.

Throughout Panay Island, four hundred forty-eight fatalities were reported, at least eight people were injured, five bridges were destroyed, and thirty-five schools were demolished. A total of 4,014 homes were destroyed; consequently, over 24,000 people lost their homes.

Location_with_Annotation.Philippines: Typhoon Agnes, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Undang, was the fourth final tropical cyclone to affect the Philippines during the 1984 Pacific typhoon season.
Location_with_Annotation.Vietnam: The next day, Typhoon Agnes moved ashore Vietnam while still at typhoon intensity.
Location_with_Annotation.Thailand: The storm rapidly deteriorated over land and dissipated by November 8 over Thailand.
Location_with_Annotation.Samar Island: The storm then made landfall on Samar Island, part of the Philippines, at that intensity.
Location_with_Annotation.Iloilo province: In the Iloilo province, 230 people were killed and four others were injured.
Location_with_Annotation.Capiz province: In the Capiz province, 265 people died and property damage amounted $25 million (1984 USD).
Location_with_Annotation.Panay Island: Throughout Panay Island, four hundred forty-eight fatalities were reported, at least eight people were injured, five bridges were destroyed, and thirty-five schools were demolished.
Location_with_Annotation.Roxas: Around 80% of houses in Roxas, located in Capiz, were damaged and 100 people were killed.
Location_with_Annotation.B\u00ecnh \u0110\u1ecbnh Province: The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries.
Location_with_Annotation.Borongan: Shortly after attaining maximum intensity, the typhoon continued west-northwest and made landfall 10 km (6.2 mi) south of Borongan on Samar Island.
Location_with_Annotation.Qui Nh\u01a1n: Agnes made its second landfall on November 7 40 km (25 mi) north of Qui Nhơn in Vietnam.
Location_with_Annotation.Leyte: President Ferdinand Marcos declared a state of emergency for the provinces of Capiz, Iloilo, Aklan, Antique, Leyte, and eastern Samar.
Location_with_Annotation.Aklan: President Ferdinand Marcos declared a state of emergency for the provinces of Capiz, Iloilo, Aklan, Antique, Leyte, and eastern Samar.
Location_with_Annotation.Antique: President Ferdinand Marcos declared a state of emergency for the provinces of Capiz, Iloilo, Aklan, Antique, Leyte, and eastern Samar.
Location_with_Annotation.Tacloban: This area also covered the cities of Roxas and Tacloban.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: Damage in the country totaled $90.7 million, with $19.1 million from crops and $56.9 million from public infrastructure.

Total_Economic_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: Damage in the country totaled $90.7 million, with $19.1 million from crops and $56.9 million from public infrastructure.

In Vietnam, the typhoon severely affected the rice harvest and winter crop cultivation. The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened. Throughout the country, the storm destroyed 271,000 hectares (670,000 acres) of farmland.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: Damage in the province amounted to at least $5 million.
In the Capiz province, 265 people died and property damage amounted $25 million (1984 USD).

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: Typhoon Agnes, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Undang, was the fourth final tropical cyclone to affect the Philippines during the 1984 Pacific typhoon season.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: An area of disturbed weather developed near the equator and the Caroline Islands on October 28. Following an increase in organization, the cyclone was designated a tropical storm on October 31.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: Agnes brought widespread damage to several provinces across the central section of the archipelago. In the Iloilo province, 230 people were killed and four others were injured. Provincewide, a total of 21 homes were flattened, resulting in 1,326 homeless people.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Landfall: The storm then made landfall on Samar Island, part of the Philippines, at that intensity.

Total_Summary_Building_Damage.Total_Building_Damage: More than 200,000 homes destroyed, 163,056 other dwellings damaged, 400 schools, 230 nurseries, 35 schools demolished
Total_Summary_Building_Damage.Total_Building_Damage_Annotation: More than 200,000 homes were destroyed while 163,056 other dwellings were damaged. Damage in the country totaled $90.7 million, with $19.1 million from crops and $56.9 million from public infrastructure. The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened. Throughout Panay Island, four hundred forty-eight fatalities were reported, at least eight people were injured, five bridges were destroyed, and thirty-five schools were demolished.

Total_Building_Damage_Per_Country.Building_Damage_with_annotation: More than 200,000 homes were destroyed while 163,056 other dwellings were damaged. Damage in the country totaled $90.7 million, with $19.1 million from crops and $56.9 million from public infrastructure.
The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Building_D.Num_Building_Damage: 21 homes flattened in Iloilo province, 80% of houses in Roxas damaged, 4,014 homes destroyed in Panay Island
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Building_D.Building_Damage_with_annotation: In the Iloilo province, 230 people were killed and four others were injured. Provincewide, a total of 21 homes were flattened, resulting in 1,326 homeless people. Damage in the province amounted to at least $5 million. Approximately 20% of the rice crop was destroyed in Iloilo. In the Capiz province, 265 people died and property damage amounted $25 million (1984 USD). Around 80% of houses in Roxas, located in Capiz, were damaged and 100 people were killed. Throughout Panay Island, four hundred forty-eight fatalities were reported, at least eight people were injured, five bridges were destroyed, and thirty-five schools were demolished. A total of 4,014 homes were destroyed; consequently, over 24,000 people lost their homes.
The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened.

In Vietnam, the typhoon severely affected the rice harvest and winter crop cultivation. The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened. Throughout the country, the storm destroyed 271,000 hectares (670,000 acres) of farmland.

Throughout Panay Island, four hundred forty-eight fatalities were reported, at least eight people were injured, five bridges were destroyed, and thirty-five schools were demolished. A total of 4,014 homes were destroyed; consequently, over 24,000 people lost their homes.
The Bình Định Province suffered the brunt of the typhoon, where 134 people died and 289 sustained injuries. There, 400 schools and 230 nurseries were flattened.
